awd_titl_txt: BD Spokes: SPOKE: WEST: Collaborative: MetroInsight: Knowledge Discovery and Real-Time Interventions from Sensory Data Flows in Urban Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The MetroInsight project is building an end to end system for knowledge discovery from real-time data streams collected through a variety of sensors, data collection and aggregation methods.  These data streams are highly dimensional with multiple sensors observing same or similar phenomena over multiple sensory spectrums and scales. These are also sometimes real-time and/or have strong timing relationships that is necessary to support metropolitan infrastructure through effective analytics and policy support. The project brings together a diverse number of partners utilities, universities, companies and cities with the ability to contribute novel tools and urban sensor data and to translate knowledge into actions. MetroInsight's unique combination of tools, data and partnerships, in part with the MetroLab Network , makes it well poised to set an example for the MetroLab programs across the nation as well as the rest of the municipal governments. The project will explore connections between multimodal datasets and urban infrastructure management to build a practical system consisting of integrated tools, as well as training a new generation of metropolitan workforce. As part of an ambitious plan for community building and workforce development, the project includes creation of new learning modules, certification programs on energy and sustainability, an online courses on sensor data analytics and new capstone projects in a new Data Science master's degree program.

To achieve project goals, MetroInsight is building infrastructure for managing data, networks and processing that will support design of new algorithms and tools in the project. Specifically, the project is developing algorithms to transform multimodal urban data to a lower dimensional data that reflects underlying physical and social phenomena. These low dimensional data may consist of population level data suitable for dynamic processing to support real time monitoring and visualization by cityscale operators of various lifelines from transportation, communications to emergency response. To address technical challenges in complex and subtle spatiotemporal dynamics of interdependent urban networks, MetroInsight will develop metadata methods and tools that support discovery of operational interdependencies, quantification of uncertainties for decision support and to provide assurances related to integrity and security of data, compliance related to ethical and legal privacy expectations.

por.por_cntn:
Sensors have become important sources for data about physical and human spaces around us. Sensors embedded in IoT devices and in smartphones provide valuable information for near real-time decision making and for longer-term modeling for strategic planning. The goal of the MetroInsight project - a collaboration between Arizona State University, UCLA,  and UCSD (lead institution) - was to build an end-to-end system for knowledge discovery using highly-dimensional sensor time-series and real-time data streams to support the metropolitan infrastructure through effective analytics, workforce development and policy support. The project aimed to overcome the data deluge caused by noisy multimodal urban sensory data. The MetroInsight team sought to engage with a strategically chosen set of partners to access specialized metropolitan data sources, and to help build communities of data producers, data consumers, application developers, and researchers.

Firstly, the researchers at UCLA collaborated with a multi-institutional team to develop Brick (http://brickschema.org/), a schema designed to bring order to the heterogeneous data generated by buildings in a city. Buildings form an important part of the city, and the data generated by a building is useful for its operation as well as management of the grid and transport in a city.  However, the data is heterogeneous in nature, and requires extensive manual transformation by domain experts before it can be consumed by applications The schema defines a concrete expressive, queryable ontology for sensors, subsystems and the relationships between them, which enables portable applications to be created for buildings. Brick uses easy to understand Tags and TagSets to specify sensors and subsystems in a building, with tags and tagsets organized in an ontology with class hierarchies.. Starting out with eight canonical smart building applications across six real buildings in the USA and Europe, Brick has in the past 2-3 years has gained considerable adoption including by companies. In particular the MetroInsight researchers were a key part of an effort orchestrated by Johnson Control International to create a formal standard around Brick.

Secondly, the UCLA team collaborated with researchers at IBM to explore sensor data driven decision making for water management. Specifically, we developed a platform for water data management and query to facilitate working with water data available from multiple sources having different resolutions. To introduce the research and user communities to this platform, we jointly presented tutorials that described the platform for water data management including data ingestion and query services along with mobile application for user engagement and data dissemination. 

Thirdly, the UCLA research team together with the MetroInsight researchers at UCSD created a software infrastructure for spatiotemporal sensor data collection, storage, querying, and spatiotemporal access control mechanisms.  The open-source software platform, called Citadel, has a service-oriented architecture based around modern web technologies. Additionally, the UCLA researchers actively integrated into Citadel several data sets and data sources relating to EV charging data, and solar generation data by drawing upon testbed facilities for EV charging at UCLA campus as well as from six locations in the greater Los Angeles region. 

Fourthly, during the project researchers developed algorithms that address various challenges that inevitably accompany the collection and sharing of data. One such challenge is that the collected data often has measurements that are missing or improperly timestamped. Another challenge is that sharing raw sensory data often unwittingly leads to leakage of private information. UCLA researchers developed a novel approach that uses Generative Adversarial Networks to synthesize novel sensor data traces that preserve essential statistical characteristics, and also allow repair of missing and bad data.

Lastly, as part of our education and workforce development initiatives, we engaged with the Los Angeles Computing Circle (LACC), a summer outreach program organized by faculty members and graduate student volunteers. We created and taught a module on Web API and Databases to Grade 9-12 students. The module was designed based on the MetroInsight research experience. MetroInsight’s aim is to provide API and database for city scale data sets at one common place. The focus of the module was to introduce students to the existing Web API’s providing multiple data sets of cities and ingesting data into the database. The MetroInsight team at UCLA also hosted or co-organized several workshops to help build communities, including one at UCLA focused on Autonomous and Electric Vehicle Technology, Grid and Communications Infrastructure in a Smart City, and additional ones co-located with major conferences focusing on privacy (SafeThings) and Ai in the context of IoT (AIChallengeIoT and AIoT).

The research conducted under the project has been disseminated via papers in various Computer Science conference proceedings and journals, as well as open source software. The research at UCLA engaged SEVERAL graduate students and undergraduate students, who were trained in cross-disciplinary issues at the intersection of sensor data collection and processing, big data management, machine learning methods, and system software implementation.
